title: Sri Lanka’s monthly fuel bill rises to $700 mln in April – CPC
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s monthly fuel import bill has risen to 700 million US dollar in April from 450 million two months ago as increased global oil prices and higher demand including for power generation have resulted in higher spending.

Sri Lanka’s average monthly fuel import bill was 311 million dollars last year, but it has started to rise mainly after the global oil prices started to increase after expectations of Russian attack over Ukraine in the latter part of last year.
Sri Lanka spent 430.3 million US dollars for fuel in January, the central bank data showed.

“We are now spending 128 US dollar per barrel of diesel and 121 US dollars for petrol,” Sumith Wijesinghe, the chairman of state-run fuel retailer Ceylon Petroleum Corporation told a media briefing on Monday.

A severe drought has compelled Sri Lanka to use fuel for power generation despite the country is facing a severe dollar shortage. The lack of fuel import has resulted in extended power cuts. (Colombo/April 11/2022)
